I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The proposed knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will help the Government 
of Mongolia strengthen agriculture value chains and promote sustainable and efficient agriculture 
production. The TA will improve the capacity and ability of herder cooperatives to address issues 
including livestock, pasture, and water management and strengthen value chains and links with 
markets.  The  TA-generated  knowledge  will  also  provide  an  evidence-based  model  for 
empowering herder cooperatives and allow Mongolia to transition towards sustainable and 
quality-based livestock production.  
 
2.  The  government  requested  the  TA  from  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  for 
Cooperative-Based  Sustainable  Agriculture  Production  to  prioritize  quality-based  livestock 
production over quantity-based output.1 The TA is included in the country operations business 
plan for Mongolia, 2020–2021.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Agriculture  remains  a  key  source  of  poverty  reduction  and  employment  in  Mongolia, 
employing one third of Mongolia’s economically active population and contributing just over 12% of 
gross domestic product. Livestock contributes 84% of agriculture output, and an estimated 230,000 
herder households rely on livestock for income and livelihood. Despite the importance of agriculture 
and livestock to poor rural households, many herders continue to manage livestock and pasture 
privately without adequate regulations, policies, and incentives for sustainable livestock, pasture, 
and water management, which has impaired the development of more climate-resilient and profitable 
livestock production and marketing systems in Mongolia. As a result, over 70% of Mongolia’s 
pastureland is now degraded and livestock heads exceed 66 million.  Well-functioning herder 
cooperatives could offer several services to members beyond just buying and selling livestock, 
including marketing, production, insurance and financial services, access to training, agriculture 
technology and extension services, and arrangements for collective and sustainable livestock, 
pasture, and water management.   
 
4.  While the number of pasture user groups and herder cooperatives has grown in recent years, 
several challenges constrain the ability of herder cooperatives to lift herder incomes, promote 
sustainable livestock production, and boost Mongolian meat exports. First, the structure, function, 
and role of herder cooperatives remains somewhat unclear, particularly after Mongolia traded 
socialism for capitalism in 1992, disbanding state-run herder collectives, privatizing livestock, and 
deregulating public pastureland.3 In addition, many cooperatives have yet to establish reliable links 
with veterinary services, agribusinesses, processors, and exporters, limiting their ability to access 
high value domestic and international markets for members. Finally, limited arrangements for 
coordinated  grazing  management,  lack  of  trust  among  members,  and  insufficient  capital 
accumulation for operating and investment needs remain important issues for herder cooperatives.   
 
5.  Cooperatives, herders, and government officials have limited knowledge and capacity. 
Cooperatives lack the capacity to deliver improved services to herders for sustainable livestock 
and pasture management and animal health, nutrition, quality, and traceability. Although large 
herds give herders additional status and diversity of herds, they also contribute to overgrazing,

desertification,  excessive  resource  use,  and  inadequate  animal  feed,  particularly  in  winter. 
Meanwhile, herders have limited knowledge about services, rights, entitlements, responsibilities, 
and profit-sharing mechanisms within herder cooperatives. To realize their potential, herder 
cooperatives must expand their knowledge. Additionally, it is important for national and local 
government officials to (i) build capacity and awareness of the key challenges faced by herder 
cooperatives  and  (ii)  support  evidence-based  models  for  cooperatives  that  can  promote 
sustainable, quality-oriented, efficient, and climate-friendly livestock production.  
 
6.  To diversify the economy and boost exports of livestock products, the government must 
review existing policies and introduce new ones for meat exports, including through herder 
cooperatives. Limited institutional coordination and policy support for cooperative-driven and 
high- quality meat exports have kept export volumes of livestock products below their potential. 
Policies and arrangements remain inadequate to ensure animal traceability, safety, and product 
quality required for exports. Animal diseases, including foot-and-mouth disease, are prevalent 
and persistent, and the veterinary system has been unable to promptly and effectively work with 
herder groups and cooperatives to contain and manage outbreaks.4 These animal disease 
outbreaks have led Mongolia’s neighbors to periodically ban Mongolian meat exports.5 However, 
Mongolia’s proximity to major regional markets in Northeast and Central Asia, and its reputation 
for pastoralist traditions, suggests the potential to significantly boost exports  and incomes, 
particularly if cooperatives can strengthen food safety standards and product quality and diversity, 
and thereby help Mongolia integrate into regional and global value chains.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
7.  The  TA  is  aligned  with  the  following  impact:  competitiveness  and  sustainability  of 
Mongolia’s agriculture sector improved (Mongolia Sustainable Development Vision 2030).6 The 
TA will have the following outcome: sustainable, quality-based, and efficient livestock production 
policies and action plans developed.7 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
8.  Because critical challenges face the livestock subsector as Mongolia looks to move 
towards  climate-friendly,  sustainable,  and  quality-based  livestock  production  systems,  it  is 
essential  to  develop  new  knowledge,  technologies,  and  models  for  strengthening  and 
empowering herder cooperatives as one promising avenue for improving the sustainability and 
competitiveness of the livestock subsector. The proposed TA will comprise four outputs that will 
generate new knowledge and build capacity to adopt improved agriculture practices and policies.  
 
9.  Output 1: Improved herder cooperative structures developed. The TA will identify the 
challenges and constraints faced by herder cooperatives in coordinating grazing among herders; 
address collective livestock, pasture, and water management issues to improve the quality of livestock 
output  and  strengthen  market  linkages;  and  propose  recommendations  for  strengthening  and 
empowering herder cooperatives. It will investigate (i) issues internal to cooperatives, such as 
cooperative structure, self-sufficiency status, organization, management and marketing capacity, profit

management and distribution, and public awareness initiatives, and (ii) cooperatives’ links with 
veterinary services, agribusinesses, processors, and exporters. The TA will produce a research and 
diagnostic  study  report  identifying  the  issues  and  actions  required  to  enhance  the  fiscal, 
administrative, and organizational capacity of herder cooperatives so that they are self-sufficient 
and have the capacity to not only address collective livestock, pasture and water management 
issues, but also strengthen value chain linkages. 
 
10.  Output 2: Model structures and arrangements for herder cooperatives in selected 
soums tested. Based on the findings and recommendations from output 1, the TA will test new 
models and arrangements for herder cooperatives and pilot practices such as (i) sorting livestock 
commodities based on quality within a single location for supplying to manufacturers and producers; 
(ii)  supporting  cooperatives  in  signing  collective  livestock,  pasture,  and  water  management 
agreements with local soum governments; and (iii) exploring other initiatives for promoting animal 
traceability, product quality, and livestock health. The models will also test the capacity of herder 
cooperatives to deliver a package of services, including storage, transportation, quality assurance, 
and marketing for herders. Successful models can help cooperatives better support herders to avoid 
middle-agents and capture greater profit margins for themselves and their families.   
 
11.  Output 3: Capacity of herders and Ministry of Food, Agriculture and Light Industry 
staff for sustainable livestock production and management improved. The TA will prepare 
training materials and deliver training and capacity building to herders and government staff on 
herder cooperatives and sustainable livestock production. Training will focus on quality-based 
production, sustainable livestock, pasture and water management, and minimal preventable 
waste. It will also raise awareness of the value of cooperatives and their rights, entitlements, 
responsibilities, and mechanisms for profit sharing and distribution. The knowledge generated 
through this TA will also help to enhance the capacity of staff at the Ministry of Food, Agriculture 
and Light Industry, improving their understanding of cooperative constraints, structures, and 
opportunities based on sound research and empirical evidence.  
 
12.  Output 4: Meat export policies from the herder cooperatives perspective examined. 
The TA will examine existing meat export policies as they relate to herder cooperatives, and how 
policy support and arrangements for herder cooperatives can boost Mongolian exports of meat 
and livestock products. This will involve consultations with important sector stakeholders to review, 
discuss, and seek consensus on policy reform recommendations to be proposed to strengthen 
the ability of herder cooperatives to link with key market agents, stabilize market supply, and 
upgrade the quality of Mongolia’s livestock products. Importantly, all proposed policy reforms will 
be  linked  with  ongoing  initiatives  to  modernize  sanitary  measures  to  support  meat  export 
expansion.8   
 
13.  Lessons learned. Previous projects indicated that involvement and inputs of senior 
national and soum government officials, concerned government agencies, and local experts in 
TA deliverables including draft reports and review workshops are important in ensuring quality 
outputs that meet the needs of various stakeholders. For policy research, greater benefits stem 
from more strategically planned dissemination to enhance knowledge-sharing activities and 
showcase the findings and recommendations under the TA, which may be relevant for other 
geographic regions, aimags (provinces), and soums with similar challenges. ADB also recognizes 
 
8  ADB. 2016. Technical Assistance for Strengthening International Food Safety Standards in Agriculture Value Chains 
in Central Asia Regional Cooperation Countries. Manila; and ADB. 2018. Technical Assistance for Modernizing 
Sanitary and Phytosanitary Measures to Facilitate Trade. Manila.

4 
the need to collaborate with specialized agencies.9 The project team will coordinate closely with 
other development partners, including the Swiss Agency for Development and Corporation, the 
Japan International Cooperation Agency, the Food and Agriculture Organization, and the World 
Organization for Animal Health, to ensure complementary activities and outputs. Additionally, the 
TA will incorporate and draw lessons from previous projects and facilitate knowledge-sharing and 
cooperation with other ongoing projects working with herder cooperatives.10  
 
14.  Strategic fit. The proposed TA is aligned with the government’s strong commitment for 
sector reform based on its Law on Development Policy and Planning, 2015, the pasture protection 
law under consideration for parliamentary approval, and Sustainable Development Vision 2030 
(footnote 6), which considers the agriculture and livestock sector a top priority; ADB’s country 
partnership strategy for Mongolia, 2017–2020; and ADB’s Strategy 2030, which aims to promote 
poverty  reduction,  rural  development,  inclusive  growth,  and  sustainable  agriculture  practices, 
particularly through the operational priority of promoting rural development and food security.11 
Among other objectives, the operational priority of ADB’s Strategy 2030 seeks to improve market 
connectivity and agricultural value chain linkages. The TA is also consistent with CAREC 2030 
strategy to promote regional trade in agriculture by aligning sanitary measures with international 
standards and building capacity on product quality.12 Finally, given the growing interest in working 
with agriculture and herder cooperatives to strengthen market linkages and promote sustainable 
agriculture, this TA will investigate the key issues affecting cooperatives and generate knowledge 
that can be used to inform both ongoing and future projects in Mongolia.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
15.  The TA is estimated to cost $450,000, of which $400,000 will be financed on a grant basis 
by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-6). The key expenditure items are listed in 
Appendix 2. 
 
16.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of remuneration and travel 
expenses of counterpart staff; government data and studies for the TA consultants’ use; meeting 
rooms, office facilities, and geographic information system maps; and other in-kind contributions. 
The government has been informed that the approval of the TA does not commit ADB to finance 
any ensuing project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements

Department and will work closely with counterparts. ADB will engage consultants and carry out 
procurement following the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its 
associated project administration instructions and/or staff instructions. The implementing agency 
will (i) provide project management support and carry out day-to-day TA activities, such as 
overseeing the TA consultants’ work; (ii) organize peer reviews and comments on consultants’

18.  Consulting services. ADB will engage a consulting firm following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions 
and TA staff instructions using a biodata technical proposal and the quality- and cost-based 
selection method.13 The quality–cost ratio will be 90:10 because of the high technical complexity 
of the consulting assignment. Disbursement of the TA proceeds will follow ADB’s Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). The consultants will 
submit progress reports, which will be reviewed by ADB and the government. 
 
19.  The TA will require 44 person-months of national consulting services. ADB will recruit a 
firm to provide national expertise, comprising a cooperative and/or livestock specialist as the team 
leader, a policy and/or institutional specialist, an agriculture economist and financial specialist, 
and a project coordinator and training specialist. International resources persons may also be 
recruited by the consulting firm on an as needed basis to review the consultants’ outputs and 
share knowledge during workshops, following ADB’s guidelines on recruiting and administering 
resource persons. For international resource persons who may be hired as needed, there is a 
preference for those with prior experience working in Mongolia, an understanding of the country 
context, and familiarity with concerned government institutions.  
 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis to the 
Government of Mongolia for Cooperative-Based Sustainable Agriculture Production, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.

Key Activities with Milestones 
1.  Improved herder cooperative structures developed 
1.1 Assess existing models of herder cooperatives, examining issues such as cooperative structure, self-
sufficiency status, organization and management capacity, herder membership management, profit 
management and distribution, and marketing initiatives using Central and Khangai regions as case 
studies, by month 6.  
1.2 Examine  cooperatives’  interaction  with  other  community  and  value  chain  actors,  including 
agribusinesses, processors, exporters, veterinary services, and soum governments, by month 6. 
1.3 Provide practical recommendations for improving the fiscal, administrative, and organizational capacity 
of herder cooperatives, so that they are self-sufficient and have the capacity to address collective 
pasture, livestock, and water management, as well as strengthen value chain linkages, by month 6. 
1.4 Submit assessment and recommendations as part of the research and diagnostic study report of output 
 
1 by month 6.  
 
2.  Model structures and arrangements for herder cooperatives in selected soums tested 
2.1 Draw on findings from the research and diagnostic study to pilot new models and structures for herder 
cooperatives, including pilot testing the practice of sorting livestock commodities based on quality within 
a single location, supporting herder cooperatives to sign collective livestock, pasture, and water 
management arrangements with  local  soum governments,  and delivering  training to  herders on 
production quality, animal traceability, and livestock health, by month 12.  
2.2 Prepare rigorous analytical findings from pilot studies, sharing pilot results, key challenges, successes, 
and lessons learned, and submit them as a report 14 months after the start of TA.  
2.3 Generate detailed cost–benefit analysis for each model to demonstrate the economic and financial 
viability of herder cooperatives as vehicles for strengthening value chains and market linkages, as well 
as supporting sustainable agriculture development, by month 14. 
 
3.  Capacity of herders and MOFALI staff on sustainable livestock production and management 
improved 
3.1 Develop and prepare training material for herders, focusing particularly on quality-based livestock 
output; sustainable livestock, pasture, and water management; minimal preventable waste; and animal 
health and safety (to be used as part of pilot study), by month 6.  
3.2 Deliver training to herders during pilot studies based on training materials developed and help raise 
awareness  on  the  value  of  cooperatives  and  herder  rights,  entitlements,  responsibilities,  and 
mechanisms for profit sharing and distribution, by month 8. 
3.3 Revise and update training material based on results, lessons, and feedback from pilot studies; herder 
cooperatives; and herders themselves by month 16.

8  Appendix 1 
3.4 Deliver training and capacity building to MOFALI and government officials on herder cooperative 
structures, constraints, and opportunities, based on lessons from the diagnostic report (output 1), pilot 
studies (output 2), and international experts’ experience with herder cooperatives, by month 16.  
 
4.    Meat export policies from the herder cooperatives perspective examined 
4.1  Review Mongolia’s meat export policies, as well as importing countries’ policies and standards, from 
the perspective of herder cooperatives, examining if and how efficient models for herder cooperatives 
can boost Mongolian exports of meat and livestock products, by month 16.  
4.2 Assess ability of herder cooperatives to strengthen linkages with key market agents, stabilize market 
 
supply, and upgrade quality of livestock output, by month 16. 
4.3 Prepare policy report on cooperative-driven meat and livestock exports, providing an assessment of 
 
existing policies and recommendations for how herder cooperatives can be better linked with export 
markets and policies, by month 18.  
 
TA Management Activities 
Mobilize the consultant team by month 3. 
Develop study framework, prepare the inception report, and conduct the inception workshop by month 5. 
Prepare the interim report and conduct the interim workshop by month 12. 
Prepare the draft final report and conduct the final workshop by month 20. 
Carry out knowledge dissemination by month 23. 
Finalize the TA outputs by month 24.
